History (PGN): b3 b6 Bb2 Bb7 Nf3 Nf6 g3 g6 Bg2 Bg7 O-O O-O d3 d6 e4 e5 c4 c5 a4 a5 Na3 Nc6 Nb5
Commentary: I don't believe I would ever have played this move in this type of position. But what to play instead? It turns out 12...Nd4? is very dangerous, as after 13.Nfxd4 neither recapture is safe: 13...cxd4 14.Ba3! and 13...exd4 14.e5! The only move I can think of, 12...Ne8, at least goes towards the thematic pawn break by ...f5, and also aims to exchanging the KING's knight for White's intruder after ...Nc7 at some point. If White were to respond (to 12...Ne8) by 13.Ne1, then 13...Nd4 becomes playable.

Commentary: Now it becomes one of those study puzzles. The puzzle sets a trap. You can either rescue your rook or...in this case the or is setting a mating net. You know it's there, since the queen is close, the pawns prevent a king from escaping, you just have to find it now.

Commentary: Zaitsev Variation - quite trendy back in 1990. Also very playable are 9...Na5 (Tchigorin), 9... Nb8(Breyer), 9...h6 (Smyslov). In this position, Black appears to have completed his development; White's Q-side has hardly stirred. This might look bad for White, but it appears that Black can do little to hinder the realisation of White's potential for improvement. Bear in mind this game was played between the two strongest players in the world at the time.

All my 'analysis' consists of the thoughts that I wrote down at the time, some just immediate stream of consciousness, others flights of fancy & an occasional genuine attempt to work out plausible variations. I generally try to go back after the game and see how this compares with any analysis by Gameknot's engine to see what I or my opponent did differently or to compare the body of established opening theory. I offer to share with opponent so that they can defend themselves and if so, I make it public - otherwise, it just stays as a private testimony to how far awry my own bizarre thought processes are!

e4 c5 f4 d6 d4 cxd4 Bc4 e5 Nf3 Nf6 Ng5 Be6 Bxe6 fxe6 Nxe6 Qd7 Nxf8 Rxf8 O-O Kf7 fxe5 dxe5 Qh5+ Kg8 Qxe5
Commentary: If the queen is in the center of the board and finds herself battling the op's queen, the decision is to either equalize the queens into rooks and less; or capitalize on moving to a stronger position. I didn't see any and had anticipated this sort of trade out eventually with our queens. The King's Gambit makes chess beyond 8 moves eccentrically complicated. That's why I ALWAYS use the King's Gambit against Ruy Lopez! Ruy Lopez is slow and long and tiring to do while the Gambit suddenly sharpens the board into few critical moves in messes created by King's Gambit offense!

Commentary: An unconventional response to the English Opening. Since White usually plays c4 in d4 openings, transposition between the two is easy; therefore Black tends to avoid ...Nc6 so as to keep the c-pawn free.

Commentary: Played, presumably, to prevent a Black minor piece landing on g4. Of course, White won't want to weaken his K-side by 15.h3, if he can help it. But it so happens that White's 14th move opened up a whole different possibility: to do something with the light squares at b5 or d5. So the odd-looking 15.Nb1 Ne8 16.Nc3 ... came into consideration. Were Black then to play 16...Nc7, White should withhold the further knight move to d5 or b5, in favour of further development: 17.Qe2, followed by 18.Re1 or 18.f4. Black's Q-side would be sufficiently tangled to encourage White to try for K-side operations.

All this should demonstrate that a Knight jumping behaind enemy Pawns can be very dangerous.

Commentary: 1. Immediate threats : none 2. center : white has a far better control on it (N,P,DSB,Q indirectly) fired. 3. Pawn structure : slighly bette for white because of the doubled pawn. 4. Open files : one (and a central one !). under black control... for the moment ! Still a clue in the game. 5. Safety of the kings : Both kings are safe. The advance of the f awn has weakened the black king but white has no more LSB. 6. Material equality : black has the 2 bishops, which is an advantage, especially in open games. 7. General disposition : the white pieces are more active (having more mobility) but 2 of them are unprotected.

I know I can potentially lose castling with this move but an exchange of queens and a bishop for my knight and my queen is not too bad in terms of material and without the queens it's a bit safer for my king to not have the castling ability vs having queens and more pieces on the board. The more pieces on the board the more dangerous it is for the king to stay in the center usually, unless it's somehow a very fixed position or board where pawns are stuck against each other and bishops, knights, rooks, queens are cramped.

The diagonal obviously bothers black too as Na5 forcing the Bishop back to the c2-h7 diagonal is the most popular and currently the only move played at high levels. History (PGN): e4 e5 Nf3 Nc6 Bb5 a6 Ba4 Nf6 O-O Be7 Re1 d6 c3
Commentary: GE shows this as a small white advantage (0.24 after black's move - in openings GE tends to fluctuate quite a lot after each player's move, so I tend to average its view of black & white during openings) Bg4 is slightly less popular than 7... 0-0 but both are currently played in high level competition - black players who favour the line with 7.... Bg4 include Romanishin, Petrosian and Janowski As White it turns out that I have simply followed the trend and played the most popular line in every move since black played 1....e5 I've played Ruy Lopez as white for over 45 years and this is my standard fare - at one time I had some success with exchange (4. Bxc6) and deffered exchange versions but RL probably has mopre theory than any other opening line so I tend to know the mainlines for white and just stick to them - if I tried to re-invent the wheel, I doubt that my version would be as good as the original.

History (PGN): d4 Nf6
Commentary: Accelerated London system. Resembling the Colle System, white develops the Bishop to Bc1-f4 the hallmark of the London. The orthodox move order has always been on the 3rd move, e.g., 1. d4 2. Nf3 3. Bf4 to what ever Black plays. The Accelerated London develops the bishop on move 2. I'm not a Londoner so I'm not going to write the pros and cons of The orthodox London vs the accelerated London system and how it is meant to deal with Black's moves. I just know it's really in vogue right now and a hot opening for White because Magnus Carlsen has played it. I will add black will face a blunted King's Indian Defense if both sides were to develop their own system, i.e., The london system vs the King's Indian Defense. For example, 1. d4...Nf6 2. Nf3...g6 3. Bf4...Bg7 4. e3...d6 5. Be2..0-0 6. 0-0.

History (PGN): e4 c5 Qf3
Commentary: What I don't like about e6 here is that he can push with 3) e5. But, after 3) e5, I can do Nc6 and how does he defend the pawn? He can't use the d pawn because of my c pawn's central presence. He can't use the g Knight because of his queen being in f3. Can't use his c bishop (at least immediately because it's blocked by his own pawns. He can only use the queen. By moving his queen (twice at this point) in the opening around the board I might be able to attack it by developing my other knight to f6, pushing my pawn to d6, depending where he moves his queen to defend the pawn.

History (PGN): e4 e5 Nf3 Nf6 Nxe5
Commentary: Black should not continue to copy White's moves and try to restore the material balance immediately with 3...Nxe4?!. After 4.Qe2 Black cannot play 4...Nf6?? because 5.Nc6+ wins the queen, and after 4...d5?! 5.d3 Qe7 6.dxe4 Qxe5 7.exd5 Black loses a pawn. Relatively best for Black is 4...Qe7 5.Qxe4 d6 6.d4 dxe5 7.dxe5 Nc6, and after for example 8.Nc3 (8.Bb5 is also good) 8...Qxe5 9.Qxe5 Nxe5 10.Nb5 (or 10.Bf4) White has a clear advantage.

Commentary: Finally getting the rook to e1. The danger here for black is the very simple Nd6+ getting the queen for a rook. Black must now lose the right to castle. Of course he still can in this situation, but there's the very simple Qa7 which has to be played very solidly by black to avoid mate I believe, and which affords a lot of opportunities to develop with tempo,while black's pieces remain mostly stuck.

When you have already created an opening in your kingside, you do not want to let your opponent get rid of your bishop when he still has his own to attack that diagonal.
Revenge is sweet! After losing badly in the first match I was very nervous about this one. Especially as I have a bad record against >1600.

I found out later that 4....d6 transposing into a King's Indian Defence is most common here, but I decided to follow what I think was a suggestion by Bill Hartston in his book on the Grunfeld.

If White plays Qh4 at some point I may have trouble defending against Qd8#. What a revolting development THAT would be! Plan B: scratch …Nd5 altogether and aim for Nh7, Ng5, and maybe Nf3(+) eventually while creating a potential back door escape for my king. The down side of this move is that it takes away h6, a square I would need to line up my major pieces on the h-file for an attack on White’s exposed king. Oh well, maybe my knight can fill in for my rook.

I decided to annotate this game I had here in this site just to share, both because I found it interesting and fun and because I think it illustrates quite nicely the dangers of underdevelopment. This is also a game where despite our ratings we "only" did a couple mistakes, and three blunders. Most moves are machine-approved. Despite that, this will obviously just contain my low-rated thoughts and a little machine analysis. I'll annotate some tactics I saw and some tactics the machine saw. If anyone ever reads this, this is my first time doing this so I'm sorry if I do it wrong, and I hope you enjoy. I won't be able to provide much theory because I myself don't know much yet. My objective here is just to show a fun game, explaining my reasoning to hopefully make others enjoy it, too. Any comments are more than welcome :) So to start, the very common e4.

Not only does this look cool (15..cxb5 16. Bxb5+ and my laser bishops will force Rd7), but more importantly, this allows me to get my Nc3 into action! Notice that prior to this, my Nc3 has no good squares to leap forward--b5 and d5 were taboo, my pawn clumsily blocked e4, and my bishop occupied e2.

History (PGN): e4 e6 d4 d5 Nc3 Bb4 e5 b6 Qg4 Bf8 Nf3
Commentary: ! Ma come! Il Nero prima sviluppa e poi ritira un pezzo nella casa di partenza, per poi 'sviluppare' per prima la Donna, per di più in una casa apparentemente priva di senso! In realtà d7 è la casa più naturale per la Donna in questa posizione perchè: 1) Il Bianco può giocare più avanti per attuare la spinta f2-f4-f5, quindi il PNero rinforza la casa f5 2) Con la Donna in d7 il Nero rende possibile una futura spinta ...f7-f5 poichè la Donna controlla la casa g7, anche se nel frattempo l'Af8 si è mosso 3) il Nero può progettare una futura spinta ...f7-f6 e quindi il Pe6 è difeso (dando per scontato che l'Ac8 vada in a6 o b7...) 4) Il Nero di solito gioca ...0-0-0 in questo tipo di posizioni, quindi muovere la Donna in d7 è un primo passo in questa direzione 5) il Nero gioca questa mossa aspettando che l'Af1 del Bianco si muova e solo allora giocare ...Aa6, guadagnando un tempo. Mi pare che tutte queste considerazioni depongano a favore della profondità dell'idea di Petrosian Alternative variation: 6...Ba6 [!? Non è sbagliata ma è poco flessibile, nel senso che dichiara troppo presto le proprie intenzioni; 6...Dd7, lasciando tutte le porte aperte, risponde di più alla massima di Nimzowitsch secondo la quale "la minaccia è più forte dell'esecuzione della minaccia stessa"] 7.Bxa6 Nxa6 8.O-O Qd7 9.Ne2 Ne7 10.Ng3 Alternative variation: 6...Ne7 7.Bg5 Qd7 8.h4 h5 9.Qf4 Ba6 10.Bxa6 Nxa6 [=/] [Spassky, B - Huebner, R , Venezia 1989 Match - questa e un'altra partita di quel match le ho viste live!] Alternative variation: 6...Nc6 7.a3 Bb7 8.Bd3 Qd7 9.Ne2 [!] [Boleslavsky, I - Yuhtman, J - Moscow 1956]

Commentary: (?!) It is possible that White was taken by some beguiling tactical features here: the immediate threat Qxf7ch, and the possibility of a knight-fork on c7 after the exchange on d5. Mirages: they disappear like smoke in a move or two. A much stronger bid for counter-play called for the delayed development of the bishop: 13.Bf4! Nxe5 14.Re1 Qc5ch 15.Kh1 Nc6 16.Ne4 Qb6 17.Nd6ch Kf8 18.Ne4. The displacement of Black's King would be at least partial recompense for the lost pawn and vacant centre.

History (PGN): e4 c5 Nc3 Nc6 a3 d6 Nf3 Nf6 Bc4 e6 d4 cxd4 Nxd4 Be7 O-O Bd7 b4 O-O Nxc6 Bxc6 Bd3 h6 b5 Bd7 a4 Rc8 Bb2 b6 h3 d5 e5 Nh7 Ne2 f6 Nf4
Commentary: However, I suddenly changed my mind and I did not take the pawn. Again, I accepted the weakness in e6 in order to attack with bishop and queen on the king side. Bishop in d7 is very passive, but bishop in e7 is very offensive, on both sides. If this bishop is then attacked by Ng6 and lost, the queen can be moved on the black diagonals, in a very effective way. Another (better) reason why I did not take the e5 pawn is that this guy is now blocking his own b2 bishop (this bishop fianchetto is now no longer bothering me at all: he is inoffensive now).

Commentary: This is The Petrov's Defence, also known as The Russian Defence. Though this symmetrical response has a long history, it was first popularised by Alexander Petrov, a Russian chess player in the mid-19th century. In recognition of the early investigations by the Russian masters Petrov and Carl Jaenisch, this opening is called the Russian Game in some countries.

Commentary: This move creates the Sicilian Najdorf which is possibly the most analysed position in chess and in my opinion Blacks best chances for a win against 1.e4. The alternative 6..g6 leads to the famously sharp Sicilian Dragon which has many adherents. But I prefer the Najdorf From here there are many continuations for White including 6.Bg5 and 6.Be3 which are probably the strongest continautions for White.

Commentary: Now after she played Kc8 I thought I might have to run over and stop the pawns on the kingside before I got over run by her majority, I didn't see a clear way for me to quickly promote to finish her off. As it turns out I didn't need too. 44. c7, h5 And I caught my breath. I saw a possible mate that I could play given that she didn't promote and ruin things. I spent a good long 20 mins making sure things would work as planned, I didn't want to lose because I missed some tricky sacrifice or pawn maneuvering. But in the end I figured that I would promote just before she could promote with check. Why did she not play gxh3 when she could have? Probably she was just tired and wanted to play a move contrary to what I expected, but neither move mattered since I had the pawn mate on b7. With the king trapped, there was nothing she could do.

History (PGN): c4 e5 Nc3 Nf6 g3 c6 Bg2 d5 d4 e4 cxd5 cxd5 Bf4 Bb4
Commentary: I give this move a “?!” evaluation, which may seem a little harsh, but it fails the “smell” test on several levels: 1. It violates the opening principle of not moving the same piece twice. 2. It concedes the bishop pair. 3. It concedes a tempo. 4. Presumably White was contemplating 8.… Rxb8 9.Qa4+ b5 10.Qxa7, but rear area raids by a lone queen frequently rebound upon the raider’s head, and such is the case here. Stockfish analysis gives the continuation 10.… Rb7 11.Qa6 O-O 12.Rc1 Qc7 13.a3 Rb6 14.Qxc8 Qxc8 15.axb4 Qc4 16.e3 Qxb4 17.Ne2 Qxb2 18.Rb1 Qa3 a score of-6.50, which may well be why my opponent chose the better part of valor.

History (PGN): e4 c6 d4 d5 Nc3 dxe4 Nxe4 Nf6 Nxf6+ exf6
Commentary: Gameknot engine (GE) gives as +0.72 after white's move and level after black's move so I'd guess it's fair to iner around +0.36 advantage to white which is I imagine a small advantage (getting your nose in front in horse racing parlance) I used to play Korcnoi Caro-Kann (exf6) as black many years ago but gave up in favour of Larsen (gxf6) because of the greater attacking potential of the open g file but I had some successes with Korcnoi and was happy to play a couple of training games with my friend Nick who is learning the opening as black - hence this is a wholly unrpresentative game - I've played this as black dozens of times, these are his early attempts I played Nf3 now as that was, in my day, the mainstream line that I was most indecisive against- c3 was more common, probably better but more obvious progression and as black I was always comfortable Nick tells me that modern thinking is that Nf3 is not as strong because 2 of its usual options (g5/e5) are covered by the f6 pawn. It seems to like bishops on e6 & d6 presumably to go both ways depending which side White castles. Nf3 accelerates black castling + Re8+ as it takes away the options of those games where white plays Ne2 and then has the choice of castling king side or queenside (I say that becase people always say white can castle queenside and have the momentum on K-side attack with a pawn charge but I don't really remember seeing that too many times) and of course a real benefit of Ne2 is Ng3 Nf5 if white has the K-side attacking momentum

History (PGN): e4 c6 d4 d5 Nc3 dxe4 Nxe4 Nf6 Nxf6+ exf6 Nf3 Bd6 Bd3 O-O O-O Re8 Re1 Be6 c4
Commentary: Notable pivot from GE here - after white's move white was +0.54 and after black's still +0.52 White is inching ahead although GE doesn't suggest anything wrong with ....h6 or affer any alternative For white, I either want to get to an end game with a passed pawn and as few pieces left on the board as possible or I want to play c4 and d5 Black wants to stop the Rook exchange and add support to d5 c3 is probably more normal than 10 c4 but stubborn players like me will try to play c4 at any opportunity Discussed with nick that potential c5 is annoying but more serious is the d5, cxd, cxd, Bxd5, Bxh7+, Kxh7, Rxe8, Qxe9, Qxdd5 Black has lmited options for N, moves c5 is more powerful as a potentlial fake threat - if white plays it, it reduces the tension on d5 (as Nick immediately realised) 10....Nick saw that h6 has the advantage of creating a bolthole for the king and also leaving B a pawn up with an early White d5 and even considered h5 in keeping with the opening theme but rejected it because it leaves the pawn hanging when the White Q reaches d5, attacking d6, b7 and h5. Nick didn't really like h6 as it may become a target but white has the threat of Qc2 and black runs out of tempi (can't play Qc7!!!) so Nick concluded that the better options are h6 or perhaps Be7, preventing d5 and not allowing a rook exchange c5 looks flashy but d5 is what gets white some really crushing lines - - if white gets b3,c4, d5 pawns and also gets Bb2, f4, Nf5 and active rooks then the minute the white queen gets to join the k-side attack, black is really struggling - h6 can be so useful for black because if you don't play that then if white gets his knight into play black faces all sorts of threats involving Bd3, Qh5, Ng5 or Nf5 (if it comes via e2 & g3), Bb2 - one trick that recurs for white is d5 cxd5 cxd5 Bx d5 Qh5 threatening Qxh7 and winning the bishop

History (PGN): e4 e6 d4 d5 Nc3 Bb4 e5 b6 Qg4
Commentary: ! Questo è quello che viene ormai unanimemente chiamato 'Sistema Petrosian'. Questa mossa paradossale viola apparentemente almeno tre principi dell'apertura classicamente intesa: 1) Non muovere due volte lo stesso pezzo, a meno che non sia strettamente necessario (e qui non lo è) 2) Non retrocedere con un proprio pezzo 3) Non rimanere indietro con lo sviluppo. Eppure questa ritirata 'ipermoderna' ha una sua logica che si pò esprimere in questi punti: a) Il vantaggio di sviluppo del Bianco è negato dal fatto che la posizione del Nero è priva di punti deboli e completamente chiusa b) il vantaggio di spazio del Bianco è negato dal fatto che il Nero (e non il Bianco) controlla il 'dove e quando' delle rotture pedonali, potendo scegliere il timing di ...c7-c5, ...f7-f6 o ...f7-f5, mentre le due spinte naturali del Bianco (c2-c4 e f2-f4-f5) sono molto più complicate da organizzare. Questo porta a dire che questa continuazione contro-intuitiva ha una sua logica, è giocabile ed è più forte delle varie alternative Alternative variation: 5...g6 [?!] 6.Nf3 h5 7.Qh3 Ba6 8.Bxa6 Nxa6 9.O-O Bxc3 10.bxc3 c5 11.Bg5 [Computer "Rebel" - Jussupow, A, Ischia (ITA) 1997] Alternative variation: 5...Kf8 [relativamente migliore] 6.Nh3 ( 6.Bd2 [! /\ 0-0-0] ) c5 7.a3 Bxc3+ 8.bxc3 Qc7 9.Bd2 Ba6 10.Bd3 Bxd3 11.cxd3 c4 [?!] ( 11...Nc6 [!?] ) 12.Nf4 Qc6 13.O-O $16 [Faibisovich, V. - Taimanov, M., 1973 USSR] Alternative variation: 5...Ne7 [? la peggiore] 6.Qxg7 Ng6 7.Qh6 c5 8.a3 cxd4 9.axb4 dxc3 10.Nf3 [Schaffarczyk, A - Thiessen, J , Werther (GER) 1998]

History (PGN): e4 c5 Nc3 Nc6 Bb5 Nd4 Bc4 e6 Nge2 Nf6 O-O d5 exd5 exd5 Nxd4 cxd4 Re1+ Be6
Commentary: Moving one of the attacked pieces with tempo which is why black's 8th move does not win a piece. And now we see why a6 should have been played before d5. It would have eliminated this option for white. Black's last move pinned his light square bishop to his king rendering it unavailable for interposition duty. So he must either move his king or interpose his knight. Okay, the queen can interpose too, but that would be silly. So if black had played Be7 last move he could play Bd7 here, developing another piece instead of moving a developed piece a second time. He also would have the option of castling on his next move, freeing his pinned pieces.

History (PGN): e4 e5 Nc3 c6 d4 exd4 Qxd4 Qe7 Nf3 d5 Bd3 Bf5
Commentary: bf5 the previous move was one of the two mistakes. Funnily enough, the GK machine does want me to go Bg5 here and then castle queenside. The point is that after castling, the f pawn doesn't win the bishop because the e pawn is no longer pinned. After that, and exchanging queens on d4 my king is quite safe and black's king ends up very exposed. It'd go: 7. Bg5 f6 8. O-O-O Qb4 9. Rhe1 Qxd4 10. Nxd4 Kf7 to avoid a discovered check I believe. SF on the other hand recommends castling first. So at first glance, this probably seems like a very easy decision, but I spent some time on this. I wanted two things in this position and I wasn't sure which to do first: either to develop the dark squared bishop and bring the a rook into the game, or to get the king to safety and unpin the pawn. I ended up going with castling because it both allowed me to get a rook to e1 faster (threatening to pin the bishop, the queen, or both) and because it allowed me to not commit to moving the bishop just yet.

(a lethal pin!) 15...Rc8 (The knight can not move, so needs protection) 16.Nd5 Qd7 17.Rc1 ... Stacks on the Mill (remember that game as a kid?) White has now 3 pieces attacking the pinned knight, and Black can find just two defenders. So the knight would have fetched up in White's pocket.

It could also be that by taking with the knight the bishop is forced to take because it can't really go to e6 with Ng5 coming and forcing black to lose tempo to preserve it or try to develop anyway with everything in the way. I thought Bxe4 would be the move that would most tempt black to take as it threatens the bishop and Bxe5 when takes a bishop. My plan since O-O was to make development as difficult as possible for black (and if possible, take everything that managed to escape).

He refuses any trade and moves his Queen somewhere in a safe position, still defending his Rook, of course. Again, I take strategic control of "d". After having analysed the 3 options, I was happy because in any case I was able to get advantage. Looking at option 3 in more details, I think he only had 2 possibilities with the Queen: a) 33. La vecchia variante 7... a5 (dopo Cc3) è stata praticamente demolita dopo 8.Te1 Ce4 9.Dd3! con controllo decisivo sulla casa e4, e ora se il Nero vuole ottenere una partita giocabile deve perdere un tempo rientrando nello stonewall con d6-d5.

Decided to annotate this game just to show what I'm thinking as I play. I'm an average player and know little about classic opening strategies and I'm often baffled reading 2000+ rated player annotated games. g3 opening as plan to fianchetto my Bishop as it's sometimes missed by opponents and can sometimes win the a8 Rook if they're careless.

History (PGN): e4 c6 d4 d5 e5 c5 c3 Nc6 Nf3 Bg4 h3 Bxf3 Qxf3 cxd4 cxd4 Nxd4 Qc3 Nc6 Be3 d4 Bxd4 Qxd4 Qxd4 Nxd4 Bd3 O-O-O Be4
Commentary: It's kind of a multi purpose move. First I want to develop my second knight, quickly. If the e pawn recaptures mine, the knight comes out next. If the bishop retreats to d3, some discovered attack could follow. If the bishop goes to c2, knight captures. It is kind of odd, I did not predict this at all, but it feels like the bishop does not have many squares left.

My aim right now is generally just to try to play solidly so most of my openings are just me following that principle. bg5 is actually a pretty good move as it either forces f6 which stops black from developing the knight effectively or forces black to exchange queens leaving white with three very active pieces against the wholly undeveloped black. All other moves are quite bad for black.

d4 Nf6 c4 e6 Nf3
Commentary: But he avoids it, instead going into a Queen's Gambit Declined. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Queen%27s_Gambit_Declined#:~:text=The%20Queen's%20Gambit%20Declined%20has,has%20a%20useful%20defensive%20role. The Queen's Gambit Declined has the reputation of being one of Black's most reliable defenses to 1.d4. In this situation, White will try to exploit the passivity of Black's light-squared bishop, and Black will try to release it, trade it, or prove that, while passive, the bishop has a useful defensive role.
This move is a bit odd to me, because the Knight blocks the Pawn in c2. Unless, his intention is to castle on the long side.

There was no easy win then, but once my knight came over it was hard to defend. Strangely enough, GK evaluates this move as the second blunder, though SF thinks it's the best move. I think GK has a point, though, because the f6 pawn would always be an easy target. It goes like this: 18. Nf3 Ke8 19. Nh4 Nc5 20. Qxf6 Nd7 21. Qd6 Nb6 22. Nf5 Rd7 23. Qe5+ Kd8 24. Rxd7+ Nxd7 25. Qh8+ Kc7 26. Qxa8 f6

Commentary: INSTRUCTIVE ERROR #3 White now throws away his draw by painting himself into a corner as though he were a lone king aiming for a stale­mate against a king with an advancing pawn. In this, the actual position White needs to stay behind his pawn to shield it from Black’s rook. For example, after 59.Kd5 Rd1+ 60.Kc4 Kf2 61.b5 Ke3 62.b6 Rb1 63.Kc5 Ke4 64.Kc6 Ke5 65.b7 Ke6 66.Kc7 Rc1+ 67.Kb6 Black must keep White in check to prevent his pawn from promoting, and White can simply shuffle his king between b6 and c6 to keep Black’s king at bay.

Commentary: I keep misplaying thing, must be a focus thing, I don't know, but my opponent was playing generally stronger than me. In a sense, that is the one psychological advantage I had: we both knew he was stronger, so it was easier to underestimate the pieces that were left. I would have done exactly the same or worse in my opponent's situation.

I was playing for Sheffield University 2 in the BUCA (British University Chess Association). I can't find out much more about my opponent. He seems to have played in the British Under 18s in 1974. He doesn't seem to be still playing. This BUCA tournament was held in Edinburgh. I think it is the only time I played in it, I think the other years Sheffield University only enter one team, who actually won it a year later in 1977. This is from round 4 and the only game I still have from the event. I scored 2.5 out of 5 overall.

Commentary: The e pawn led by that d3 pawn put the dagger in the heart of the king. It was a fierce and great play from white. White was very courageous, its strategy was to bombard the kings castled position with force which was very valid but was few steps behind due to the slow development of its officers at the beginning. The awkward start-up of black and its pawns position at the beginning became an advantage which made it difficult for white to land its officers close by and in turn helped black into the game and eventually seizing the centre for a effective overrun of white in the middle game.

I went for either King's Indian or Nimzo-Indian (After knight to f6 I think either Nimzo or King Indian Automatically. I had used the King's Indian last time and thought this time use the otherwise well known "Nimzo-Indian Attack" which is not listed here as a "chess opening!" I wonder why? The next moves are pretty automatic for white but somewhere in the next few moves I realized he had no idea what the Nimzo Indian Attack was with the White Queen open! Maybe he will pull a rabbit out of his hat!

History (PGN): d4 g6 c4 Bg7 e4 d6 Nc3 Nf6 Be2 c5 d5 Nbd7 Nf3 O-O O-O a6 a4 Rb8 Qc2 h6 Re1 Ne8 Bf1 Nc7 a5 Kh7 Bf4 b5 axb6 Rxb6 e5 dxe5 Nxe5 Nxe5 Bxe5 Bxe5 Rxe5 Qd6 Rae1 Bf5
Commentary: !? In post-mortem, Black was insistent that White with an Alekhine's gun Qe2 would win the game outright with weak pawns on e7&f7, hanging knight-c7 and a winning endgame, if Queen's and one set of rooks were exchanged and my Re1 would be on e7. Black couldn't defend the e7-pawn and the e7-e6 pawn push would trap his Bishop with pawn g2-g4. And I saw this!!! I also saw that his Rb6 had counter play on the b-file and my weak back-rank, and a well-developed bishop on Bf5. For example, Black's Rb6 & Bf5 could've doubled team my Bf1. The checkmate is stronger than grabbing the hanging c7-Knight: this is what I thought. I noted that Black had weak squares around the King.

Does it have merit? really stifles white knight and might even frustrate his bishop a bit - and he has no light squared bishop and at this stage it's not getting in the way of my knight unless I fancy Ne4 at some stage, in which case I'd probably want to play f5 first anyway actually, I'm having a bit of buyer's remorse now - I would like to reduce down to just 2 or 3 games to focus on (currently 5 in play) but when I look at e.g. (very quick doodle, need to look at these lines properly) 11. Nc3 Rc8 12. Nb5 Bb8 13. Rac1 a6 14. Na3 Nge7 15. Rc2 O-O 16. Rhc1 Bd6 17. Nb1 Nb4 18. Bxb4 Bxb4 19. Rxc8 Rxc8 20. Rxc8+ Nxc8 then I see that the bishop is an endgame advantage- I slightly regret offering the draw now....but with only 4 games left to focus on, it makes sense from game management - I believe that I'm winning in 2 games, advantage in 1 and level in the other - have 1.5 points from the 2 finished games- I think that 4.5/6 should be good enough to make the next round, 5/6 (as always) would definitely clinch it of course

Commentary: Though I could use my bishop now, I notice a different opportunity, to temporarily counter attack the knight. The knight's squares are mostly taken by the white's own pieces, and by my advanced pawn. Of course it can be defended, but bring the rook in to defend it is a useful distraction. I get to mobilize my pieces while maintaining the threat. And when I cannot maintain the threat any longer(I expected the knight would go eventually to f1 after the rook there vacatedd its position) I go back to selling my own bishop dearly, bringing my remaining pieces to bear on f2/g3 squares.

Commentary: correct move gaining space in the area of the king is critical to successful attacks. Now all black has to do is develop pieces toward the white king. With the idea of gaining a piece majority on the kingside. There prongs of to a successful attack: #1 piece majority on the side of the opposite king #2 space majority on the attacking side. #3 open lines to the king. if you have all three in the area of the attacking zone then your attack has a high chance of success

History (PGN): d4 Nf6
Commentary: Accelerated London system. Resembling the Colle System, white develops the Bishop to Bc1-f4 the hallmark of the London. The orthodox move order has always been on the 3rd move, e.g., 1. d4 2. Nf3 3. Bf4 to what ever Black plays. The Accelerated London develops the bishop on move 2. I'm not a Londoner so I'm not going to write the pros and cons of The orthodox London vs the accelerated London system and how it is meant to deal with Black's moves. I just know it's really in vogue right now and a hot opening for White because Magnus Carlsen has played it. I will add black will face a blunted King's Indian Defense if both sides were to develop their own system, i.e., The london system vs the King's Indian Defense. For example, 1. d4...Nf6 2. Nf3...g6 3. Bf4...Bg7 4. e3...d6 5. Be2..0-0 6. 0-0.

Bobby Fischer's preferred defense.

Black's first actual move then is Nf6, the Heidenfeld variation.

This was our first home game of the season. I hadn't realised that Shrewsbury had changed their venue again, and I went to their old venue and so was about 15 minutes late for the match.

Black chooses to castle.

Black has a mobile K-side majority that ought alone to be the game-winner.

Commentary: White has opened up a route for his rook to get to h4 via f4, which will probably require me to play …h5 at some point, which will make the pin on my g-pawn all the more inconvenient, so I remove that pin now. I was somewhat expecting White to continue his king-side assault with 22.Ne2, but he (also) saw that 22.… Qd5 effectively shuts that down, for then if … • 23.Nf4 Qxf5, • 23.Ng3 Rc4, or • 23. Rc5 Rxc5 ◦ 24.dxc5 Qd3 or ◦ 24.bxc5 Qb3.

History (PGN): c4 e5 Nc3 Nf6 g3 c6 Bg2 d5 d4 e4 cxd5 cxd5 Bf4 Bb4 Bxb8 Rxb8 e3 Bd7 Nge2 O-O O-O Re8 a3 Bd6 b4 a6 Nf4 Bxf4 gxf4 Bg4 Qd2 Qd7 f3 Bh3 fxe4 Bxg2 Qxg2 dxe4 Rac1 Rbc8 f5 Kf8 Qf2 Rc6 Ne2 Rec8
Commentary: On the surface this looks like a waste of time, but when a good player – White’s rating was 2014 at the time – makes a bad move I do not automatically assume it is a bad move. 24.… b6 looks like a natural response for the rook’s only retreat that does not lose a piece outright is 25.Rcc1, there follows 25.… Rc2 26.Rxc2 Rxc2 (else 26.… Qa4 immediately) 27.Rc1 Qa4 28.Ra1 Qb3 and White’s a-pawn is lost. That leaves 25.Re5, which walks into a knight fork but looks like it works for a draw by repetition: 24.… b6 25.Re5 Ng4 26.Qf4 Nxe5 27.dxe5 (27.Qxe5 Re8 28.Qf4 f6 leaves White with no compen­sation for the sacrifice of the exchange) Rc4 28.Ng3 Qc6 29.Rd1 Rc1 30.Rxc1 Qxc1+ 31.Kg2 Qxa3 32.Qxe4 Rc2+ 33.Kh3 Qa2 34.Qa8+ Ke7 35.Qb7+ Ke8 36.Qb8+ Kd7 37.Qb7+ Rc7 38.Qxb6 Qd5 39.Qxa6 Qxe5 40.b5 Qxe3 41.b6 Rc3 42.Qa4+ Kc8 43. Qa8+ Kd7 44.Qa4+ etc. Ceteris paribus I may well have been satisfied with a draw – as the underdog against a higher rated opponent my rating would go up slightly – but this game was played in a 3-on-3 team match where each member plays two games, one with each color, against one member of the opposing team. At this juncture my two teammates had completed all their games in the match, the score was 2-2, and my other game looked drawish as well. ‘Tis said fortune favors the bold, so …

The example is whether or not to advance the pawn to King Rook Four or to take out the inside knight to break the castling or advance either pawn d or e forward or to just 0-0. That is both the problem and the decision to be loyal to the gambit instead of following simple moves to predictable near losses/wins through king and battling pawn.

General organization : white pieces are more mobile

d4 Nf6 c4 e6
Commentary: Here, obviously, White does not like to get a check by Bishop to b4 (Nimzovic variation of the Indian Defense, if I am correct). Nevertheless, I personally do not like the move Bb4+, because in most cases it leads to a Bishop loss (exchanged with the Knight, ok, but assuming the game arrives to the final phase, a Bishop is always superior to a Knight. The Knight is superior to the Bishop at beginning, but with a balanced game I always consider to get to the final phase). So, I prefer to maintain the Bishop pair as long as possible, even if I enjoy to use the Knights in attack.

History (PGN): d4 e6 Nf3 Nf6 e3 b6 Be2 Bb7 O-O Bd6
Commentary: 6. The h3 pawn push is a wasted moved and gives me an edge on development. Even though white has a castled king he is still a minimum of 3 moves from full development and that is if I do not count central placement of the rooks. I am opposed to early a or h pawn moves (when white) to the 3rd rank. This gives your opponent a hook to pry the enemy king out of hiding. There does come a point when the a3 or h3 pawn moves are needed. For instance, a castled king has a rook protecting the 1st rank, but the rook is needed else where. You open the h3 pawn in case there is a back rank check. However, early in the game I feel it is more important to develop minor pieces and gain central control. You will see this move done often when a knight is perched on g5 or b5. The knight when placed there typically do not pose an immediate threat because they need another minor piece or a pawn to truly gain a hold in your territory. There is time to deal with the threat. I find that many players will use the a or h pawn to kick the knight. They do this almost by rote like an enemy in your camp must be pushed away no matter what.

This was one of my first games on GameKnot and my first game of chess in quite some time. The loose sort of plan I opened with e4 here intending to play through the Giuoco Piano opening. I know this opening inside out. It's the first one I ever learned and was among the reasons I became my high school's champion (undefeated in the tournament too).

Petrosian abbandona il piano con ...Aa6 per attuare invece una specie di 'Est-Indiana allo specchio' con uno sviluppo del tipo ...Cc6/...Ab7/0-0-0 e pensare a rotture di pedone tipo ...c7-c5 (muovendo prima il Cc6) ma soprattutto ...f7-f6! Alternative variation: 7...Ne7 [è più normale, per es.] 8.Bb5 c6 9.Bd3 Ba6 10.O-O Bxd3 11.cxd3 Na6 12.Rac1 Nf5 [Botterill, G - Short, N - Brighton 1984 Ch Great Britain] Alternative variation: 7...Ba6 [è ovviamente coerente con il gioco precedente del Nero e quindi non è sbagliata] 8.Bxa6 Nxa6 9.O-O h5 10.Qh4 Ne7 [=/] [Vazquez, R - Freyre, J - Puerto Rico 20/ 7/2007 Ch Puerto Rico] Alternative variation: 7...Bb7 [è simile alla mossa del testo e potrebbe pure rientrare nella variante principale] 8.Bd3 Nc6 9.a3 O-O-O 10.Ne2 [Zuttioni, F - Formento, P - Lignano 5/ 8/2016]

History (PGN): e4 c5 Nf3 d6 d4 cxd4 Nxd4 Nf6 Nc3 Nc6 Bg5 e6
Commentary: After 6...e6, Vsevolod Rauzer introduced the modern plan of Qd2 and 0-0-0 in the 1930s. White's pressure on the d6-pawn often compels Black to respond to Bxf6 with ...gxf6, rather than recapturing with a piece (e.g. the queen on d8) that also has to defend the d-pawn. This weakens Black's kingside pawn structure, but in return Black gains the two bishops and a central pawn majority.

Commentary: The knight had to retreat from the bishop/queen battery. But I expected it to retreat back to f6. My opponent must have reasoned wisely that the f7 square needs more protection, and that on f6 the knight might be attacked by my pawns. Which, I felt, he had enough protection against. But now instead, for the first time, I actually have chances. That pawn structure: f7/e6 feels weaker than ever. If I were sure I have enough pieces, I might even sacrifice my knight now, where I couldn't before.

History (PGN): e4
Commentary: So he's doing Ruy Lopez and my mission is to teach him a lesson about the King's Gambit that I do in this case. Other cases where Sicilian is chosen or the French Defense I continue with THE KING'S GAMBIT aka GRAND PRIX or another name when the KING'S GAMBIT gives up an insignificant pawn on f2 to move the knight out to BLOCK that pawn that took the insignificant pawn. The pawn in the king's bishop rank is essentially useless in all games including the Reti Opening. It means nothing so get rid of it.

Hi everyone! Here is a match where I am playing a Class B player. In the middlegame both players castle on opposite sides. Black tries to create a rook line up on my kingside position whereas I somehow manage to win material which ought to be decisive by a few line openers on the queenside. However, in the endgame, despite being 5 material points up, Henry ends up in a mating net. But is there to be a Houdini Act? Read on, Inquest Jury, I say, read on!

History (PGN): d4 Nf6 Bf4 c5 e3 Nd5 Bg3 cxd4 Qxd4 Qa5+ Qd2 Nc6 Qxa5 Nxa5 c3 b6 Nf3 Bb7 Be2 e6 O-O Bc5 b4 Nxb4 cxb4 Bxb4 Rd1 d5 Bb5+ Bc6 Bxc6+ Nxc6 Rc1
e4 c6 d4 d5 Nc3 dxe4 Nxe4 Nf6 Nxf6+ exf6 Nf3
Commentary: Bd6 or Bf5 or Bg4 determines a lot about the pattern of the game Bf5 looks tempting in case white wants to play Bd3 but opens the question of does black want to exchange on d3 or play Bg6 - I used to love Bg6 variations but definitely unorthodox and probably frowned upon worked for me as black looking to attack kingside I think that Be6 used to be seen as sounder than Bg4 but it's a totally different strategic set up and it didn't really suit my simple attempts to throw the pieces around and attack K-side Bg4 was I think viewed as most aggressive but I tended to find it drifting into positional games where it was very solid, fairly even but not much counterplay - I'm not great in positions like that but you would probably navigate those more successfully into good endgames Black can just defer some of the decisions but that never worked well for me - I knew that i wanted to play Bf5 - Bg6 (have to be careful with that BTW, you can get pushed back into that h7 file corner and by dithering, that options would get taken away and I'd end up playing Bg4 and not getting the position that I wanted or even having that taken away (e.g. by h3) and end up only have Be6 available - in some ways, it might be best to know what you want and to make sure you can play it before that option gets taken away Bd6 also enables black to castle early - there are lots of disastrous examples of where that fails to happen although I was often quite comfortable not castling as black but it's playing with fire - I think this is why Bd6 and Be6 became orthodoxy

I was privileged and honoured to be able to play the beautiful and talented young player, Women International Master, Priyanka K in a game recently. I have asked for Gameknot to give a computer analysis on this game, and I will use that analysis in my annotations. As we shall see, Gameknot thinks that I made two errors. But for my opponent, Gameknot thinks she played a faultless game, an amazing achievement!

I never quite understood why, in this situation, losing a lowly pawn for the tricky knight was actually a bad deal for me. Mind you. The pawn attacking the knight in these situations would have been my Queen's Pawn. I still remember the look my father would give me to this day if I so much as brushed the King's Bishop Pawn early on. I was expecting 3... Qe7

I was very pleased at beating someone with a higher ECF (English Chess federation) grade than me, although afterwards I found out that I did have a higher Elo rating (1947 compared to 1905)

Commentary: ?! 18. Qxd7 Kxd7 1. Rxd5 is better as white gains tempo. Tempo is like having money in the bank in chess. Understanding how tempo works in chess is critical to winning. Tempo is forcing the opposition to make moves that they don't want to make. It is also playing moves that improve your pieces and position at the expense of your opponent. Thus, this is one of the main reasons why moving the queen out early is often ill advised. Your opponent often will gain an advantage by kicking the queen around.

I had a very stressful journey to the match. I couldn't leave earlier as I had a tuition session 10.30-11.30. I then found that my mobile telephone, which I was going to use to guide me to the centre, was out of mobile data. I bought myself a road atlas from a petrol station and used it to find my way to Royal Leamington Spa and then asked directions from another hotel. I arrived with about 10 minutes to spare. So I was in the mood for a quick draw, knowing that our team out-rated our opponents on most boards.

Favourite

It doesn't crop up very often but when facing Bird's Opening I like to play From's Gambit. I don't play many gambits as I don't like giving away pawns but I particularly like this variation with 4 . . g5 as black seems to have reasonable compensation.

I decided to look at this game and make an annotation at the same time White opens with e3. My father used this opening to try a quick CHECK MATE. Lets see how this game plays out. e3 does actually attack one of the middle 4 squares and f6. Join this annotation with your comments and let's see who will stay with me until the end.

This was the second game we played; nuntar beat me in the first game with a superior endgame. This time it was my turn to best him in the endgame.

I am reminded of the shipwreck where six sailors and one woman (a WAC they had picked up) washed ashore. After they were rescued, the mother of one young sailor inquired about the woman: Was she chaste? Oh yes mam, all over the island! This quick mate is easily defended and white loses momentum moving the queen about while black develops pieces. Aside from that, it is a fine move against less skilled players. In the world database white never plays 3. Qf3.

History (PGN): d4 Nf6 c4 g6 Nc3 d5 cxd5 Nxd5 e4 Nxc3 bxc3 Bg7
Commentary: He plays the old main line. For decades, theory held that the correct method of development was with Bc4 and Ne2, often followed by 0-0 and f4–f5, playing for a central breakthrough or kingside attack. It was generally thought that an early Nf3 was weak in the Exchange Variation because it allowed Black too much pressure on the centre with ...Bg4. In the late 1970s, however, Karpov, Kasparov and others found different methods to play the Exchange Variation with White, often involving an early Rb1 to remove the rook from the sensitive a1–h8 diagonal, as well as attempting to hinder the development of Black's queenside. Another, relatively recently developed system involves quickly playing Be3, Qd2, and Rc1 or Rd1 to fortify White's centre, remove White's rook from the diagonal, and possibly enable an early d5 push by White. Vladimir Kramnik and Boris Gelfand are the leading practitioners as White, and Ľubomír Ftáčnik has had many fine results with the black pieces

Commentary: "BANZAI!!!!!!11111one1111!!!!" I admit that I did not expect this play. When I was just starting out in chess club back in high school (*cough*) a few years ago (*cough*), I tended to favor this style of play, to fully expose an enemy king at the cost of a piece for two pawns. I learned a few lessons when I did that, and it was this: a) you need pieces to keep attacks alive, and b) you need to castle to the opposite side, or their defense turns into offense really, really fast.

Commentary: Yum!

History (PGN): d4 Nf6
Commentary: Accelerated London system. Resembling the Colle System, white develops the Bishop to Bc1-f4 the hallmark of the London. The orthodox move order has always been on the 3rd move, e.g., 1. d4 2. Nf3 3. Bf4 to what ever Black plays. The Accelerated London develops the bishop on move 2. I'm not a Londoner so I'm not going to write the pros and cons of The orthodox London vs the accelerated London system and how it is meant to deal with Black's moves. I just know it's really in vogue right now and a hot opening for White because Magnus Carlsen has played it. I will add black will face a blunted King's Indian Defense if both sides were to develop their own system, i.e., The london system vs the King's Indian Defense. For example, 1. d4...Nf6 2. Nf3...g6 3. Bf4...Bg7 4. e3...d6 5. Be2..0-0 6. 0-0.

History (PGN): e4 e5 Nc3 c6 d4 exd4 Qxd4 Qe7 Nf3 d5 Bd3 Bf5 O-O dxe4 Bxe4 Bxe4 Nxe4 Nd7 Re1 Kd8
Commentary: I had absolutely no interest in trading queens, which would've now been an interesting escape route for black. I missed a nice machine line here where Bg5 pins the queen and after Nf6 Nxf6 trades the queen and picks up two minor pieces along the way (though the line is maybe a little above my paygrade :P). 11. Bg5 Nf6 12. Nxf6 c5 13. Rxe7 cxd4 14. Rxd7+ Kc8 15. Rxd4 b6 16. Ne4 Bc5 17. Nxc5 Black responds with the most baffling move, which I think seals his fate. History (PGN): e4 c5 Bc4 e6 Nc3 Nc6 a3 Nf6 d3 d5 exd5 exd5 Qe2+ Be7 Bb5 Bd7 Nf3 O-O h3 a6 Bxc6 Bxc6 O-O d4 Na2 Re8 Ne5 Bd5 c4 dxc3
e4 e5 f4 exf4 Nf3 g5 Bc4 g4 O-O gxf3 Qxf3 Qf6 e5 Qxe5 Bxf7+ Kxf7 d4 Qxd4+
Commentary: An excellent move, granting tempo and getting White's DSB into the game. Black cannot take with either the queen or the pawn, forcing a choice. You can capture the bishop on e3, and more or less equalize the position in terms of points, but White is a mountain ahead in advancement. You can go after the b pawn, and hope to get the rook on a1 through sloppy play of White, or bring the queen back for defense. Personally, I like the last option, because you still need defenders to stave off any mating threats from White. SIX of Black's pieces have yet to move, meanwhile, White, although down seven points, has three very active pieces. My choice for move is 10... Qg7, as it puts the queen in a place to do good and allow the knight at g8 get into the game.

However, it weakens his knight on c3, and I have my eye on that b-pawn of his, to give my queen something to do, and to force nuntar to play solid defense to defend his light squared bishop. I know I can have his dark-squared bishop because there's nowhere to go outside of f4, which would block his rook from controlling the file.

Commentary: The person playing white is someone I've played a game with in the past, and they did the exact same move with me. I've looked at several of their games and they seem to be fond of this opening, though it rarely serves them well--in their game with me, as well as a few others, their opponent manages to capture the Queen after she comes out so early. I never like bringing my queen out in the early game because she simply ends up with nowhere to escape to since she's so tempting of a piece to capture and often ends up threatened if the opportunity arises.

History (PGN): d4 Nf6 Nc3 e6 e4 Bb4 Bd3 c5 Nge2
Commentary: That move is the clincher in the Nimzo Attack and also rather necessary. I have always found the Nimzo Attack on a White Open with the Queen is more effective than either the corner fianchetto King's Indian Defense of the other lately "standard" of just opposing the Q open with a pawn to d5. This version of defense has so many alterations to moves it is not worth getting "familiar" with and even if you did as Black you'd lose to White eventually with more consistency. If it was good enough for Aaron Nimzovich then it's GOT to be good enough for me!

Commentary: Here I forgot the advice of my mentor! I was afraid on white playing Bg5 and exchanging my Nf6 and increasing his control over d5. However as Euwe points out (I have "translated" the descriptive notation into algebraic) 7.......Be7 strategically 8. Bg5 would be a strong move, followed by 9. Bxf6 but 8....Nxe4 equalises. (a) 9. Nxe4 Bxg5 10. Nxd6+ Ke7. The knight on d6 is en prise and if (1) 11. Ne4 Qxd1+ 12. Rxd1 the position of the Black King in the centre is better than it would be on the wing - a general case in the ending or (2) 11. Nxc8+ Rxc8 and Black has nothing to fear. (b) 9. Bxe7 Nxc3 10. Bxd8 Nxd1 11. Rxd1 Kxd8 12. Rxd6+ Ke7 and Black is all right.

History (PGN): d4 Nf6
Commentary: Accelerated London system. Resembling the Colle System, white develops the Bishop to Bc1-f4 the hallmark of the London. The orthodox move order has always been on the 3rd move, e.g., 1. d4 2. Nf3 3. Bf4 to what ever Black plays. The Accelerated London develops the bishop on move 2. I'm not a Londoner so I'm not going to write the pros and cons of The orthodox London vs the accelerated London system and how it is meant to deal with Black's moves. I just know it's really in vogue right now and a hot opening for White because Magnus Carlsen has played it. I will add black will face a blunted King's Indian Defense if both sides were to develop their own system, i.e., The london system vs the King's Indian Defense. For example, 1. d4...Nf6 2. Nf3...g6 3. Bf4...Bg7 4. e3...d6 5. Be2..0-0 6. 0-0.

Sorry to start the New Year with a loss, but I felt I gave a good account for myself. I gained a slight material advantage, exchange for pawn, but his minor pieces were too active and I ended up losing. Part of the reason for doing this annotation is to find out where I went wrong, as at the moment I am not sure!

Commentary: This was a massive surprise. already I had to think for myself. I did look at d5 and eventually came to the conclusion that it was not good for white. After 3. d5 Ne5 black is attacking the c4 pawn, and e2-3 is likely to lead to the loss of tempo with e3-e4 later. I was later pleased that glances at opening databases seemed to confirmed my thoughts. Lichess says of this "With the work by Georgi Orlov this previously obscure opening has been given new life. Black keeps a flexible central pawn options. White has a number of sensible replies but the most common is 3. Nf3 to discourage the e5 break. Sometimes also called the Mexican Defense or Kevitz-Trajkovich Defense. ECO listing is A50."

Commentary: Here I was inspired by an idea that originated with Bobby Fischer. He observed that in this opening if black's king's knight is developed to f6 there is a shortage of good squares to move it to after that, so harassing it with a pawn can be quite effective. It looked to me like the same was true for his knight on g6. So in spite of his pawn on e6 I attack with my f-pawn.

Commentary: One rule of thumb at this stage is not to move a piece more than once. You're trying to get all your pieces out into the middle. You would be better off moving out the other knight or a bishop.

History (PGN): e4 e5 Nf3 Nf6 Nc3 Nc6 d4 exd4 Nd5 Nb4 Nxf6+ Qxf6 a3 Nc6 Bb5 Bc5 O-O O-O
Commentary: Now White is getting his pieces into the game to cause some challenges for Black. With this move, White's initial development is done. Black still has a Light Square Bishop (LSB) sitting in the starting blocks. This move is good for a few reasons, naturally developing the bishop, forcing the Black queen to relocate, and further ups the aggressive piece placement on my side of the board. A lot accomplished with a single move!

Open file : the f one - under white's control. 5. Pawn structures : The white one isn't very good (unsupported pawn on g5) 6. safety of the kings : the white one is weakened by the attack but the black one is worse 7. general organisation : all the pieces are protected - white has plenty of material aiming at the black king.

Commentary: At this point my theory memory ran out - 15. Be3 followed by 15. d4 are the only multiple precedents - also both 15 Nd2 and 15 a4 have each been played on one occasion I didn't remember any of that In fact, I don't think I could remember anything- I wrote to my opponent "I used to be indecisive but now I'm not so sure.... Is there such a thing as self-Zugzwang? My pieces look worse if I move them so I'm going to put them back where they came from - if I were a footy ref this is where the crowd would be chanting 'you don't know what you're doing'...." - so basically, I decided that the Knight that had just come from f1 could go back there because I wanted it on e3.... - strangely, nobody's ever done this before...... Bizarrely, after this white was still ~+0.65 average on GE
E3 signals of course the follow up of d4, so as my opponent is taking the center, I feel like a must to do the same.

My 'analysis' consists of the thoughts that I wrote down at the time I was playing the game (generally just immediate stream of consciousness, flights of fancy & half-baked attempts to work out plausible variations). I generally try to go back after the game and see how this compares with any analysis by Gameknot's engine and also compare the body of established opening theory). I offer to share with my opponent so that they can defend themselves against my thought doodles. Otherwise, it just stays as a private testimony to how far awry my own bizarre thought processes are!

Nxc6 dxc6 17. Bh5 O-O 18. Rab1 Nd7 19. f4 gxf4 20. Rxf4 It scores 8. Re1 Nc6 as +1.09 so maybe not much to choose & white eventually plays Be4 on move 11

I did find a nice knight outpost on c5 but having to play a4 and open up the queenside for his rook and queen had me really concerned. Instead of Bxa4 I could have played the better Nxa4 stopping the Queen from coming in to b6, but I was resistant to moving my knight from the outpost I had found for it. This decision should have cost me a pawn after Qc6, 23.d4, Bxd4. This seems like a logical progression, but my opponent plays Bg5+?? giving me a chance to save myself from this predicament!!! No doubt this mistake can be traced to the amount of time my opponent had on the clock, since she had already used 75 minutes of her 120.

History (PGN): e4 e5 Nf3 Nc6 Bb5 a6 Ba4 d6 d4 b5 d5
Commentary: An offer black happily accepts. It would have been better for white to withdraw his bishop to b3. In general it is not recommended to exchange a bishop for a knight. However, a temporary tactical advantage can be gained in the early stages of the game when the board is crowded and the knight's ability to jump over pieces can be helpful. Bishops on the other hand, become more powerful as the game wears on and the pieces get cleared off the board. In this position it is not clear that white's knights will be immediately useful and black decides to go with the long term advantage of the bishop pair. And so black gains the initiative. However, if white had retreated with his bishop to b3 white wins the d4 pawn and if black is not careful he loses his bishop too. E.g. 6. Bb3 exd4. If white insists on taking back the pawn: 7. Nxd4? Nxd4 8. Qxd4 c5! 9. Qd5 threatening mate on f7 and the rook on a8. 9... Be6 defending against both threats. 10. Qc6+ Bd7 11. Qd5 c4 an explosive move (thank you Ben Finegold) which traps the bishop.
Queen pawn opening.

This win came after a long poor run of form. I hadn't won any games on Lichess for at least two months, I had lost my last three serious over-the-board matches. I was playing on top board against someone of a similar rating. We had the better ratings on the other boards. I would be content to draw if that is how the game went. However, as you will see, I won this, and I was very pleased with my play. After the game I used Stockfish on the Lichess account to analyse the game, and I was pleased to see that Stockfish felt that I hadn't made any mistakes.

They could still develop, but that should take more time than it has taken me, and I already had the first move advantage. So to be honest, whatever happens, I already don't feel bad about this position.

Have you ever won a best game prize dear reader? I have, once, with this game, a long, long time ago. As I received it, I was reminded that the late, great John Littlewood had not entered any of his games, and if he had, he almost certainly would have won this prize - as well as the prize he won for winning the tournament.

History (PGN): Nc3 d5 d4 e6 Bf4 Nf6 e3 Bb4 Bd3 c5 Nf3 c4 Be2 Ne4 O-O Bxc3 bxc3
Commentary: Here is the explanation: now I attack the Queen and he cannot avoid exchanging his Bishop with my Knight. I don't want he maintains the Bishop pair (too strong). Meanwhile, because of the unbalanced attacks/defenses against the Knight, I gain a Pawn.

However, the Qf3 will not only end up completely out of play, but also turn out to be susceptible to attacks from my lowly minors. If my opponent insists on gaining revenge for his lost pawn, a better pawn to take was 10..dxe5, consuming my centre pawn on e5 and occupying the center himself. However, he would have opened the tantalising d file for me after 0-0-0

In Sicilian I seemed to get that off my back by the center of the board shifting toward Black in Sicilian; but it was enough for me to learn the Dragon and also the Shev Sicilian using that bump pawn unusual to the standard Sicilian formations. Scheveningen Sicilian is the second Sicilian I learned after the standard stuff everyone else pulls.

History (PGN): e4 d5 exd5 Qxd5 Nc3 Qa5 Bc4 Nf6 d4 Nc6 a3 g6 h3 Nxd4 Qxd4 Bg7 Bxf7+ Kxf7 Nf3 Nh5 Ng5+ Ke8
Commentary: White's choices were largely limited to Qc4, Qd3, or Qe3. I'm always wary of lining a rook or queen where it can be pinned against the king, though Qe3 would be pretty safe. The drawback with Qe3 is that it blocks white's black bishop. Qc4 is good. Black has a queen on Ng5 and could develop by pushing it, maybe, but knows white is eyeing Qf7+. Not that this would help white much, but the only protection for Bg7 is that rim knight, which is easily shoved by g4. Therefore black is wise to guard against Qf7+.

History (PGN): d4 Nf6 c4 e6 Nc3 Bb4 Qc2 O-O Bg5 c5 e3 h6 Bxf6 Qxf6 Nf3 b6 Be2 cxd4 Nxd4 Bb7 O-O Na6 Rac1 Bc5 Nf3 Nb4 Qb3 d5 cxd5 Nxd5 a3 Nxc3 Qxc3 Qxc3 Rxc3 Rac8 Rfc1 a5 h3 Rfd8 Kf1 Bxf3 Bxf3
Commentary: [?] Black was fixated on achieving the typically favorable position of paired rooks on an oppo­nent’s second rank, but overlooked that he must separate his own rooks to do so, pin­ning his bishop to the rook on the d-file. This would not be a problem if the bishop could be attacked by only a rook, but White’s next move reveals such is not the case. He would have been better off playing to clear the rooks off the board with 21.… Bd6 and seeing if his bishop pair could over­work White’s bishop and knight, though the symmetrical pawn structure suggests White’s offer of a draw was well considered. Now this move required preparation with 22.… Ra1.

History (PGN): e4 e5 Nf3 Nc6 d4 exd4 Nxd4 Nf6 Nxc6 bxc6 Bd3 d5 e5 Ng4 Qe2 Bc5 O-O Qe7
Commentary: Giving up the e-pawn at once. In this position White has more often protected the e-pawn for longer: 10.Bf4 g5 11.Bd2 Nxe5 12.Re1 ... when Black can opt for any of 12...Nxd3, 12...Bd6, 12...f6. The insertion of 10.Bf4 goes to inducing a K-side weakness in Black's structure as at least partial recompense for the pawn lost. Incidentally, after 12...Nxd3 in this line, things could get pretty exciting after 13.Qxd3 Be6 14.b4 Bxb4 15.Rxe6! fxe6 16.Qd4 e5 17.Qxb4 Qxb4 18.Bxb4 ... when White gets 2 minor pieces (and a somewhat passive position) for rook and 2 pawns.
I saw Jon Ludwig Hammer, second strongest in his country, after Magnus, playing this interesting anti English, and I was hoping to try it out, of course I ended up mixing my metaphors.

History (PGN): d4 e6 Nf3 Nf6 e3 b6 Be2 Bb7 O-O Bd6 h3 Nc6 Nc3 Qe7 a3
Commentary: 8. I am developed at this time. Typically, I would try to place my rooks in the center and create a plan of attack. However, since white is castled and he has advanced the A pawn I decided to try and use that h3 pawn as a hook to pry the enemy king out from safety. One of the tactics I use to do this is the fishing pole. I did not expect this trap to work, but I thought I would give it a try since I was ahead on development I had some time. Even if the trap failed and white did not take the bait I would be in a good position and perhaps I could force a mistake.

Commentary: GE gave + 0.99 after white's move and +0.48 after black's - white is inching towards a perceptible advantage Black can get cramped in these lines - eg Nd7 (with the plan to go to f8) can be a problem (especially against Ne2-g3 in that after f4, it can block the retreat of B on d6 - c4 is, now I think about it, probably better in conjunction with Ne2-g3 and also with f4 but the bottom line is that I often found h6 helpful but you have to be aware of tactical possibilities for white involving sacrificing Bxh6 - if Q is already on h5 then this can get messy - I remember getting caught out years ago, thinking I'd just be able to play f5 and give up a pawn to trade off the light square bishops only to realise too late that if I did then white just played Ng5..so white choices here are either 11. Be3 or 11. Bd2 to prepare that diagonal (queen can then either go to d2 or c1 or still aim for h5 - but white needs to play that in conjunction with moving the knight and also possibly opening up f4 (at some point - maybe white never gets there but just the threat of playing it might be stronger than the execution of actually playing it!)

Its not the most accurate ending, but as I heard from a NM friend of mine, "It doesn't matter how you win an endgame, just as long as you are comfortable knowing what to do." So I may not have played the most accurate moves, but I felt pretty comfortable here. I got my king into play a little faster than my opponent, and was able to threaten and win the a5 pawn, and when my opponent traded rooks on a5 it was like putting the icing on the cake. There was no way I could lose this now.

Commentary: Sooo, I don't know what my opponent was thinking when she played Bxh3. Maybe she missed that I can simply take back on e7 eliminating all counter play on her part and leaving me free to take c6. Regardless, I was able to quickly trade down material with my opponents help when she played Bxc5 which is a mistake. I think she wanted to make the position less complicated so she wouldn't miss something because she had less than 15 mins left on the clock at this time. She just wanted to get to the 40 move mark and get the additional 30 mins added to her clock. Unfortunately for her, this left me with a rather simple endgame to play.

I imagine he had the idea to give me a check with his Knight in f8 in order to take my Queen after I took his checking Knight with my Rook (Nf8+; Rxf8; Rxf1). The idea would be right, but I can simply restore the previous position with both Queens under attack... How? I simply take his Knight and the situation is the same as before, with a lost Knight for him. See after...

Commentary: One of the comments I read online about this move is "Theoretically there is nothing wrong with it. Practically, you've limited your options as black. In the Nimzo-Indian it's not always desirable to play d5 early in the opening, and in the QGD Bb4 is not really a constructive move." I agree. Black is never really threatening to double white's pawns with Bxc3 as after bxc3, white can always undouble his c pawns with c4xd5.
